docs.lead_paragraph: When a small red mark appeared on Amy Sidaway's face a few days after her birth last April, her mother did not have to ask what it was. The mother, Elizabeth Sidaway, recognized the vascular birthmark, a hemangioma or ''strawberry mark,'' because she was born with one, too. ''Our pediatrician advised us that it would have to run its course but would eventually disappear on its own,'' Ms. Sidaway said. ''I knew better.'' The two generations of the Sidaway family frame the medical establishment's evolving understanding of these benign vascular tumors and the current debates over whether and how to treat these blemishes.
docs.abstract: Doctors debate how and when to treat hemangioma, vascular birthmarks that vary widely in appearance and can negatively impact patient's emotional and physical health; hemangiomas often disappear within 10 years; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The medical establishment's understanding of these benign vascular tumors is evolving and there are debates over whether and how to treat the blemishes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting advice from a doctor is a good thing, but after a certain point enough may be enough, a new study suggests. In the current issue of Ambulatory Pediatrics, researchers report that when pediatricians cover too much ground with parents, much of the information can be lost.

headline.main: Talk, Talk, Talk: When a Doctor Says Too Much

docs.abstract: Dr Shari L Barkin of Brenner Children's Hospital at Wake Forest University Baptist Medical Center leads study on effective use of pediatric visits in informing parents about medical concerns; research, which is published in journal Ambulatory Pediatrics, holds that too much information at one time is not retained by parents; asserts that pediatricians should target areas of parental concern along with other important topics for each child and avoid too many subjects (M)
docs.snippet: When pediatricians cover too much ground with parents, much of the information may be lost.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who have chronic pain may be able to reduce their suffering by using brain-scanning equipment that lets them see their brain activity and try to modify it, researchers say. The process, which the researchers say may eventually prove useful as a treatment, is described online in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (pnas.org).

headline.main: Relief From Chronic Pain May Be a Thought Away

docs.abstract: National Institutes of Health-sponsored study suggests that individuals can reduce their pain by viewing images of their brain and using strategies to try and alter brain's perception of pain; research is described online in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People with chronic pain may be able to reduce their suffering by using equipment that lets them see their brain activity and try to modify it.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

docs.lead_paragraph: I knew from a note left by her case manager that the homeless woman I was waiting to see had a history of trauma, terrible mood swings, past suicide attempts. I had booked an hour for an intake evaluation. She arrived 35 minutes late, sat down and shook out long braids. She was plump, and wore what looked like someone else's ill-fitting button-down shirt. She opened her pocketbook, eyeliner, loose cigarettes, Kleenex tumbling out.

headline.main: In the Chaos of Homelessness, Calendars Mean Nothing

docs.abstract: Dr Elissa Ely Cases column describes her brief connection with distraught homeless woman seeking help; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A psychiatrist was just another branch floating by in a flood of confusion for a homeless patient.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's been a year since my seriously arthritic knees were replaced by manufactured titanium ones. Many readers who recall the postoperative difficulties I wrote about last February have asked for an update. They want to know how I'm doing, and whether I would do it over again if I had to. I'm going to answer these in chronological order and include caveats that may or may not apply to others who have had knee replacements or will have them in the future.

headline.main: A Year With My New Knees: Much Pain but Much Gain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses how she is fairing one year after total knee replacement surgery; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A key question on readers' minds: Would I do it over again if I had to.

docs.lead_paragraph: Answers to four simple questions may help medical workers predict when elderly people are at a higher risk of malnutrition, researchers say. In older people, weight loss related to malnutrition ''can have devastating consequences on quality of life, morbidity and mortality,'' the authors say in The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

headline.main: Quick Quiz Can Predict Weight Loss in the Elderly

docs.abstract: Margaret-Mary G Wilson of St Louis University leads research into weight loss in elderly; research, which is published in American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, finds that four simple questions can help screen for worrisome weight-loss and help stave off malnutrition; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Answers to four simple questions may help medical workers predict when elderly people are at a higher risk of malnutrition.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Eye color can be affected by the color of clothing. THE FACTS -- What if you woke up every day and your eyes were a different color? As bizarre as it may sound, some people claim that their eyes shift hues from one day to the next, or even, at times, from one moment to the next, depending on their moods or their outfits.
docs.snippet: What if you woke up every day and your eyes were a different color?

docs.lead_paragraph: A nutritional supplement widely sold as an antioxidant may help cocaine addicts give up the drug, researchers have found. The supplement, N-acetylcysteine, appears to reduce addicts' desire for cocaine.

headline.main: Supplement May Stifle the Craving for Cocaine

docs.abstract: Dr Peter Kalivas of University of South Carolina leads study that suggests antioxidant supplement N-acetylcysteine may help cocaine addicts reduce their desire for drug; research was presented at meeting of American College of Neuropsychopharmacology; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The supplement N-acetylcysteine appears to reduce addicts' desire for cocaine.

docs.lead_paragraph: In her closet, Doris Byrne has at least seven pairs of sandals to wear with her painted toenails and Capri pants, and she is shopping for more. This is far more than a fashion statement. It is a coming out celebration.

headline.main: New Drugs Offer More Choices for Psoriasis

docs.abstract: Severe psoriasis, noncontagious disorder caused by overactive immune system attacking person's own skin, can now be treated with new biological therapy originally introduced to treat arthritis and other immune-related disorders; traditional treatments for and symptoms of severe psoriasis described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Drug treatments recently developed for other autoimmune diseases are now being deployed in severe psoriasis with excellent results.

docs.lead_paragraph: Silver, one of humankind's first weapons against bacteria, is receiving new respect for its antiseptic powers, thanks to the growing ability of researchers to tinker with its molecular structure. Doctors prescribed silver to fight infections at least as far back as the days of ancient Greece and Egypt. Their knowledge was absorbed by Rome, where historians like Pliny the Elder reported that silver plasters caused wounds to close rapidly. More recently, in 1884, a German doctor named C. S. F. Crede demonstrated that a putting a few drops of silver nitrate into the eyes of babies born to women with venereal disease virtually eliminated the high rates of blindness among such infants.

headline.main: Old Curative Gets New Life At Tiny Scale

docs.abstract: AcryMed, medical device company, develops method to bind nano-size silver particles on catheters to help reduce risk of infection; silver has long been used to fight bacteria and emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria has caused some industry researchers to investigate new ways to utilize silver; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Silver is receiving new respect for its antiseptic powers, thanks to the growing ability of researchers to tinker with its molecular structure
